column1: 1|introduction|It gives us great pleasure to present this new App for Lemur-Watching; the first of its kind ever produced. This App is based on the third and fourth editions of Lemurs of Madagascar
column2: with updates since the most recent of these
column3: the French version
column4: was published in 2014. As you will see
column5: one of the main purposes of this App is to stimulate Lemur Ecotourism in the form of Lemur-Watching and Lemur Life-Listing
column6: part of a global effort to stimulate Primate Ecotourism worldwide. We hope that this new tool will further encourage people to visit Madagascar and contribute to the conservation of these very endangered creatures
column7: one of the most fascinating group of animals on our planet.

column2: Madagascar is without a doubt the world’s highest primate conservation priority
column3: with very high species diversity and unmatched endemism at the species
column4: genus
column5: and family levels. It is the second country on the world list for primate species diversity (in spite of being less than 7% the size of Brazil
column6: the world leader in this respect
column7: and roughly one-third the size of Indonesia
column9: and its 103 species (107 taxa when you include subspecies) are all endemic.1 This diversity is even more striking at the generic and family levels—fully five families and 15 genera are found nowhere else. Compare this to Brazil
column10: the richest country on Earth in terms of primate species and subspecies
column11: with 149 (85 or 57% of which are endemic); only three of its 18 genera are endemic
column12: and none of its five families.

column2: based on the most recent IUCN Red-Listing Workshop
column3: held in Antananarivo in July
column5: 87% of the lemurs are now threatened with extinction on the IUCN Red List of 2015; 24 of these are Critically Endangered
column7: and another 20 are Vulnerable. Four of the species and subspecies are currently listed as Data Deficient
column8: and the threatened status of another four species

column1: Looking at Madagascar’s primate diversity in yet another way
column2: although it is only one of 86 countries to have wild primate populations
column3: it alone is home to 15% (107 of 702) of all primate species and subspecies
column4: 20% (15 of 76) of all primate genera
column5: and 36% (5 of 16) of all primate families—a great responsibility for one single nation.

column1: Madagascar also demonstrates clearly that primate extinctions are a very real phenomenon and not just a figment of the conservationist’s imagination (see Extinct Lemurs). Fully eight genera and at least 17 species of lemur have already gone extinct on this island since the arrival of our own species there roughly 2
column2: 000 years ago. As indicated in the pages that follow
column3: many others could disappear within the next few decades if rapid action is not taken. Today
column4: the major threats to lemurs include deforestation due to slash-and-burn agriculture (known as tavy in Madagascar)
column5: logging
column7: charcoal production
column8: the seasonal burning of dry forests to create cattle pasture
column9: and live capture of lemurs as pets. Sadly
column10: the hunting of lemurs as a source of food
column11: a threat that we used to consider less severe than in other parts of the world
column12: is now emerging as a major problem in many areas. It therefore requires special attention.

column2: Madagascar is just coming out of a five-year  period of political turmoil
column3: with a coup that took place in early 2009 and a government that lasted until the end of 2013
column4: unrecognized by any other nation on Earth. Although many conservation activities continued in spite of the political problems
column5: the breakdown of law and order in certain parts of the country had serious impacts
column6: and much of it continues to the present day even under the legitimate government of President Hery Rajaonarimampianina
column7: elected in December 2013
column9: 2014. This has especially been the case in parks and reserves with valuable timber such as the national parks of Marojejy and Masoala in the northeastern part of the country. Almost immediately following the onset of the crisis
column10: illegal loggers moved into both of these protected areas. Organized hunting of lemurs for commercial purposes sprung up in that region as well
column11: but now appears to be under control—at least for the time-being—as a result of a concerted international press campaign that brought the issue to the attention of the Malagasy authorities. To further exacerbate the problem
column12: most international donor agencies suspended their support to Madagascar
column13: excepting only assistance for the most dire humanitarian situations. This suspension has included support for conservation programs from bilateral agencies
column15: and others. Most of the international and national non-governmental organizations
column17: continued to be active in Madagascar even during the crisis
column18: and we were able to maintain many of the most important programs
column19: although with far less resources. Fortunately
column20: following the election of President Rajaonarimampianina
column21: much of this foreign assistance has been reinstated
column22: but the capacity to absorb new resources remains somewhat limited.

column1: Conservation International and the Primate Specialist Group of the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Species Survival Commission (IUCN SSC)
column2: along with numerous other organizations
column3: have long recognized Madagascar as one of their top priorities. Our four editions of Lemurs of Madagascar were designed to facilitate the identification of lemurs in the field and to summarize available data on their ecology
column4: distribution and conservation status—in the hope that this would stimulate further interest in the survival of these animals in their natural habitats. The same is now true of this Lemur-Watching App. Amazingly
column5: in spite of several centuries of observation and collection and five decades of research
column6: we are still discovering new species
column7: we are not clear as to the limits of the distributions of many of the known species
column8: and we have at best only anecdotal information on the conservation status and population numbers for the majority of them.

column1: Increased field and laboratory research is showing us how little we knew of these animals as recently as a decade ago. Indeed
column2: a total of 48 lemur species and subspecies previously unknown to science have been described since the first edition of this guide was published in 1994; four of them since the fourth edition in 2014. Since 1994
column3: a further nine old names have been resurrected from the literature (Microcebus griseorufus
column4: Cheirogaleus crossleyi
column5: Cheirogaleus sibreei
column7: Lepilemur ankaranensis
column10: Varecia variegata editorum and Varecia variegata subcincta) based on a re-evaluation of the diversity of each genus2. Much of this work has been conducted by authors of this volume. As we launch this App
column11: we know of still more that await formal description
column12: along with a number of others that may be new to science but which need further investigation. All these additions will bring the total lemur list for Madagascar to well over 110 and perhaps as many as 125
column13: an amazing number for an island this size and with so little habitat remaining. Madagascar is sometimes referred to as the “eighth continent
column14: ” and for primates this is certainly the case since this particular fauna is comparable in every way to that of Africa

column1: In addition to the description of previously unknown taxa
column2: field research continues to fill the gaps in our knowledge of species once believed to be extremely rare and endangered. Two good examples are the hairy-eared dwarf lemur (Allocebus trichotis) and the aye-aye (Daubentonia madagascariensis). Both were once believed to be nearly extinct
column3: but they now continue to be found at new (though still widely dispersed) sites in different parts of the country. Neither is ever found in large numbers nor at high densities
column4: so we cannot consider their populations to be secure
column5: but their situation is certainly better than had been believed as recently as 15–20 years ago.

column2: with the description of so many new species (splitting up what were once considered wide-ranging forms)
column3: the conservation challenge increases dramatically. Indeed
column4: many of the new taxa are known only from their type localities
column5: and quite a few have tiny ranges in areas of extreme habitat fragmentation. Surely
column7: a number of these new forms are likely to enter the ranks of the Endangered and even the Critically Endangered.

column1: Given the amazing diversity of Madagascar’s lemur fauna and its great global importance
column2: it is sobering to reflect on the extent of the degradation and loss of their forest habitats. By the 1950’s only 27% of Madagascar was forested3 and this had further declined to an estimated 16% by 2005 (Harper et al.
column3: 2007; MEFT
column4: USAID and CI
column6: 000 ha of forest was destroyed each year between 2000 and 2005 (MEFT
column7: USAID and CI
column8: 2009). This equates to a current cover of about 94
column12: 2009)—an area roughly equivalent to the American state of Indiana. However
column13: it should be remembered that the fragmentation and isolation of the forest fragments is extreme. Harper et al. (2007) calculated that the area of what they termed “core forest” (forest more than 1 km from a forest edge) decreased from more than 90
column14: 000 km² in the 1950s to less than 20
column15: 000 km² in 2000. The area in patches of 100 km² or more decreased by more than half in that period.

column2: only about 3% of Madagascar’s land area was protected
column3: which corresponds to around 17
column4: 000 km² (1.7 million ha) or slightly more than the size of Connecticut
column5: and only a small portion of that was effectively managed. In light of this
column8: the Government of Madagascar committed to tripling the country's protected area coverage in five years (subsequently revised to be by the end of 2012). This pledge was announced by President Marc Ravalomanana in September 2003
column9: at the 5th World Parks Congress in Durban
column10: South Africa. This historic declaration served as a rallying point for everyone concerned for the biodiversity in Madagascar. Subsequently named “The Durban Vision
column11: ” this commitment attracted major international attention and funding.  What is more
column12: the government has made good progress towards this goal
column15: with the creation of a further 40 additional reserves covering 11
column17: there were 4.7 million ha of protected area in Madagascar
column19: NGOs and community groups were actively working to create a further 1 million ha.

column2: President Rajaonarimampianina has maintained “The Durban Vision
column3: ” and strongly reinforced it at the 6th World Parks Congress in Sydney
column4: Australia
column5: in November
column7: 11 years after Ravalomanana’s original declaration. He promised to make “official” all new protected areas created under “The Durban Vision” by May
column9: a promise that he has since kept.

column1: The international community has pledged more than $50 million to a trust fund to cover some of the recurrent costs of the country's parks and reserves
column2: a figure that was achieved by March
column4: and continues to grow. Other funds are also providing significant support to Madagascar. The Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund (CEPF)
column5: for example
column6: provides grants to non-governmental organizations so that they can conserve the world's biodiversity hotspots. In this context
column7: CEPF granted $4.25 million to 40 projects implemented in Madagascar between 2001 and 2006
column8: and $1.4 million to 10 projects from 2009 to 2012. Subsequent to this initial investment of $5.65 million
column9: CEPF has now committed another $7.5 million to be spent in Madagascar and the neighboring Indian Ocean islands during the period 2015−2020.

column1: It is hoped that this first-ever App for Lemur-Watching will make a new contribution by providing user-friendly access to the most up-to-date information and by stimulating Lemur-Watching for everyone interested. The ecotourism industry
column2: which had been growing steadily prior to the 2009 coup and which seems to be picking up once again
column3: was fully espoused and supported by the government and by private enterprise. Indeed
column4: it should continue as a major foreign exchange earner for the country
column5: providing a strong economic justification for the maintenance and protection of parks
column6: reserves and natural habitats. Since lemurs are the most attractive
column7: conspicuous and best known component of Madagascar’s wildlife
column8: they are ideally suited to stimulate the growth of ecotourism
column9: and they continue to be Madagascar’s wildlife ambassadors to the world.

column1: 2|origin|The island of Madagascar once formed part of the great southern landmass of Gondwana. This enormous supercontinent began to break apart about 180 million years ago into the individual landmasses we know today as Africa
column2: South America
column3: Antarctica
column4: Australia and the Indian subcontinent. Initially
column5: Madagascar remained attached to Africa
column7: together with the Indian subcontinent
column8: it began to break away from Africa. East and West Gondwana fragmented further
column9: but the Indian subcontinent and Madagascar remained joined together as “Indo-Madagascar” for another 70 million years before finally separating about 90 million years ago. By that time
column10: Madagascar had assumed its present position relative to the east coast of Africa
column11: separated by the Mozambique Channel. The channel is just over 400 km wide at its narrowest point.

column1: This has interesting implications for the origin of lemurs and Madagascar´s biological uniqueness. The island
column2: it was widely assumed
column3: had merely parted from Africa with a sampling of that continent’s fauna aboard. While Africa’s fauna saw a great deal of replacement of one group by another over the course of the epochs that followed
column4: the fauna of isolated Madagascar did not.

column1: If Madagascar has been essentially where it is now in relation to Africa for the past 90 million years or so
column2: we cannot explain the presence of lemurs in Madagascar by an African “founder effect” (although this may explain the presence of some of the more ancient members of the island’s biota).

column1: Divergence time estimates based on a number of studies have indicated the lemuroid dispersal to have occurred between 80 to more than 50 million years ago.

column2: even if the ancestors of the primates were much older than was previously thought
column3: and even that certain key events in mammalian evolution took place in Africa a little earlier than in the northern continents
column4: it would still seem that the ancestors of today’s lemurs most likely reached Madagascar by a sea crossing from Africa(Yoder et al.
column5: 1996; Roos et al.
column7: matted clumps of floating vegetation are routinely washed down major rivers and out to sea
column8: sometimes with unwilling mammals and other passengers aboard. Despite the width of the Mozambique Channel
column9: Madagascar’s lemurs most likely represent one more such case.

column1: There are a number of aspects
column2: however
column3: which need to be considered before accepting this as an explanation
column4: not least among them whether sea currents and winds would favor
column5: or even permit
column6: a passage from the continent where the ancestors were presumed to have lived
column7: and also whether the passage would be short enough for the survival of the unwilling passengers. This last aspect was discussed by Kappeler (2001)
column8: who indicated that torpor or month-long hibernation
column9: a trait of Microcebusd and Cheirogaleus
column10: would have contributed to the likelihood of survival of a sea passage. This was based on the incorrect supposition by Purvis (1995)
column11: that the mouse and dwarf lemurs are the most ancestral of the living lemurs. They are in fact one of the more recent lineages (see below). Stankiewicz et al. (2005) reviewed and investigated the possibilities concerning the likelihood of a sea crossing
column12: taking into account even such fortuitous events as freak winds and tornados or trees on the floating vegetation which could act as a sail. Their unequivocal conclusion was that “current and wind trajectories [as they are today] show that the most likely fate for a raft emerging from an estuary on the east coast of Africa is to follow the Mozambique current and become beached back on the African coast.”(p.1.

column1: Another possibility that has been raised is that islands or even a bridge was formed from peaks along the north-south running Davie Ridge in the Mozambique Channel at times when sea level was lower
column2: which could have facilitated a crossing (e.g.
column3: Tattersall
column4: 1982; McCall
column5: 1997; Masters et al.
column6: 2006). This would have occurred during the second half of the Eocene and the idea that it might have allowed for the lemur colonization of Madagascar by the ancestral lemur was suggested by McCall (1997) based on a divergence time for the lemuroids and lorisoids at about 40 million years ago A land bridge has also been discounted for geological reasons (Rabinowitz and Woods
column7: 2006) and even if there were small islands at some time during the Cenozoic
column8: they still would have been separated by hundreds of kilometers of ocean (Ali and Huber 2010). Krause et al. (1997) suggested that the currents in the Mozambique Channel may have been favorable for a crossing from Africa to Madgascar in the Late Cretaceous
column10: when Madagascar and Africa layed about 15º further south from where they are now. This possibility was strongly supported by Ali and Huber (2010) who
column12: concluded that in the Eocene epoch strong currents in the Mozambique Channel certainly would have flowed eastward and that there were occasions when so-called “trajectories” starting in the region of northeast Mozambique and Tanzania would have fast
column13: jet-like eddies with velocities indicating that crossings to Madagascar could have been possible in 25–30 days or even less. Ali and Huber (2010) concluded that favorable currents would have persisted through the Oligocene
column16: would have breached the margin of the subtropical and equatorial gyres by the early Miocene
column17: and currents thereafter would have been perennially directed westwards

column1: All subsequent genetic analyses have confirmed lemur monophyly
column2: i.e.
column3: all lemurs are the descendants of a single successful colonization event (Yoder et al.
column4: 1996; Roos et al.
column5: 2004; Yoder and Yang
column7: Karanth et al.
column9: 2008). Supporting the findings of Roos et al. (2004) and Yoder and Yang (2004)
column10: Hovarth et al. (2008) concluded that the diversification of lemurs on Madagascar began with the separation of the lineage leading to the aye-aye (Daubentonia)
column11: about years ago 54.9–74.7 million years ago
column12: extending as such across the Cretaceous/Tertiary boundary of 65 million years ago. Current evidence indicates that further splits of lemurs into families did not begin to occur until about 42 million years ago
column13: more than 20 million years later in the middle Eocene
column14: but the possibility remains that there were unrecorded lineage extinctions during this time (Yoder and Yang
column15: 2004). The first major divergence in evidence today
column16: following that of the separation of Daubentonia
column17: was between the “true” lemurs (Lemuridae) and the ancestors of the Cheirogaleidae
column18: Lepilemuridae and Indriidae. The indriids subsequently separated
column20: all within a period of about 10 million years (Yoder and Yang

column1: Madagascar is the last place on Earth to have experienced the disappearance of diverse groups of large indigenous mammals (megafauna)
column2: and one of the last habitable continental regions to be colonized by humans. Most of the documented extinctions occurred after the ﬁrst arrival of humans on Madagascar
column3: about 2
column4: 000 years ago (Burney et al.
column5: 2004). The earliest date for man’s presence came from cut marks suggesting the removal of flesh from a radius bone of a sloth lemur (Palaeopropithecus ingens) dated at 2

column2: relatives of the ostrich
column3: the largest of which stood 3 m tall and at 450 kg probably the heaviest bird that ever lived
column4: were still present on the island near the end of the of the first millennium A.D.
column5: as were at least 16 species of large
column6: now extinct lemurs. The stratigraphic resolution of this megafaunal “extinction window” is estimated to have been between 500 and 1
column7: 500 years ago. At least 53 species of large Malagasy mammals
column10: leaving the region with no indigenous terrestrial vertebrates of a body weight greater than 12 kg.

column1: In the next chapter we discuss in more detail the nature
column2: natural history of the 17 large and remarkable lemurs that tragically are now extinct. Their loss emphasizes that the lemurs surviving today could face a similar fate if major conservation efforts currently underway are not effective.

column1: 3|extinctlemurs|Since the arrival of humans on Madagascar
column2: fully eight genera and at least 17 lemur species have gone extinct (Figs. 3.3 and 3.4). This represents 15% of all known species of lemurs and over one-third of all known genera
column3: and it is noteworthy that all of the now extinct species were larger than those that survive today. There are 73 living primate genera and these eight extinct lemur genera represent as such a loss of 10% of the world’s primates in historic times. This loss of lemurs in Madagascar in geologically very recent times is a dramatic example of the kind of extinction spasm that conservationists are constantly warning us about and
column4: indeed
column5: many of the surviving lemur species could fall victim to the same fate if conservationists are unsuccessful in their efforts. We describe this extinct fauna in order to convey some sense of the catastrophic loss of primate diversity that this unique island has already experienced
column6: in the hope that it will make us redouble our efforts to save those that remain. A century ago
column7: C. I. Forsyth Major (1894a) described the first subfossil remains of giant extinct lemurs recovered from marshes in the center and southwest of Madagascar. Not only were these remains clearly those of lemurs much larger than any which survive today
column8: they were equally clearly of no great antiquity (hence the “subfossil” appellation). In a review published as early as 1905
column10: was able to show that many more names than necessary had been bestowed upon the large collection of subfossil lemur bones that had been amassed by that time. However
column11: among those names were most of the extinct genera recognized today. Despite extensive excavations during the first half of the century
column17: no new extinct lemur genera were recovered between the first decade of the century and the late 1980s. In 1986
column18: a team led by Elwyn Simons of Duke University began work in karst caves on the Ankarana Massif in the far north of Madagascar. Besides discovering at least one new genus of extinct lemur (Babakotia)
column19: this team has made finds that have caused considerable rethinking of the adaptations of the extinct lemurs and the relationships among them. The team also made finds indicating that species that still survive today
column20: among them Prolemur simus and Indri indri
column21: once had much more extensive ranges. Until the mid-20th century
column22: subfossil lemurs were known almost exclusively from the center
column23: south and southwest of Madagascar. Now
column25: the only major biogeographic region of Madagascar where subrecent fauna remains unsampled is the eastern rain forest. Perhaps even more importantly
column26: the recent era of fieldwork has allowed the collection of complete or relatively complete skeletons in which skulls and the various elements of the body skeleton are positively associated. This contrasts with earlier excavations in which bones tended to be dredged up one by one from swamps and muddy marsh bottoms. Given such circumstances of excavation
column27: the association of postcranial bones with skulls and with each other tended to be a matter of guesswork and size-matching. As it turned out
column28: this was not the most accurate procedure. Most of currently known subfossil sites consist either of marsh deposits (dried to varying extents) or of deposits washed into limestone caves or fissures. Most such sites are rich in the bones of many other vertebrates besides primates (living as well as extinct). Common among such remains are those of pygmy hippopotami
column29: giant tortoises and the famous elephant birds (Aepyornis and Mullerornis). Of particular interest is the Ankilitelo pit cave in the karst landscape of the Mikoboka Plateau in southwestern Madagascar. It has a uniquely rich subfossil mammal fauna (34 species in all)
column30: which is very recent (around 500 years old)
column31: making it one of the most diverse Holocene assemblages in Madagascar (Simons et al.
column34: 2009b). It is an extraordinarily rich repository for five species of extinct giant lemurs: Palaeopropithecus ingens
column45: 2005). All of the subfossil sites are strictly localized
column46: and all are of comparatively recent age. Most radiocarbon dates that have been obtained so far cluster in the period between about 2
column49: and only one or two stretch back to the final millennia of the last Ice Age
column51: 000 years ago. These are not very ancient ages by any standard
column52: and they show that subfossil and living lemurs all form part of the same contemporary fauna; the extinct lemurs are in no way the precursors of those that still survive.
